title: Trysail
text:
A trysail (also known as a spencer) is a small triangular or square <a href="fore-and-aft">fore-and-aft</a> rigged <a href="sail">sail</a> hoisted in place of a larger <a href="mainsail">mainsail</a> when winds are very high. The trysail provides enough thrust to maintain control of the ship, e.g. to avoid ship damage, and to keep the <a href="Bow%20%28watercraft%29">bow</a> to the wind. It is hoisted abaft (i.e., directly behind) the <a href="mainmast">mainmast</a> (taking the place of the much larger <a href="mainsail">mainsail</a>) or, on a <a href="brig">brig</a>, abaft the <a href="foremast">foremast</a>. A trysail is analogous to a <a href="storm%20jib">storm jib</a>.
Royal Navy usage.
In the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> in the late nineteenth century, the term 'trysail' came to denote the main fore-and-aft sail on any mast. This included the mainsail of the 'great brig' <a href="HMS%20Temeraire%20%281876%29">HMS "Temeraire"</a>, the largest fore-and-aft sail ever used by a <a href="warship">warship</a>. Naval trysails were usually <a href="Gaff%20rig">gaff-rigged</a> and 'loose-footed', with a <a href="Spar%20%28sailing%29">spar</a> along the <a href="Parts%20of%20a%20sail%23Quadrilateral%20fore-and-aft%20sails">head</a> but no <a href="Boom%20%28sailing%29">boom</a>, and small auxiliary trysails continued in intermittent use into the 1920s for <a href="seakeeping">seakeeping</a> and <a href="Nautical%20stationkeeping">station-keeping</a>.
